entries.title: THE CREATIVE FORAGER
entries.summary:
Using Wild Ingredients in the Kitchen

HEY, YOU! YES, YOU WITH THE EYEBALLS! GO OUTSIDE AND EAT SOME WILD FOODS!

Food is all around us, if you learn where to look, and how to prepare it. This is a book about how to use wild plants in the kitchen. Think of it as inspiration and techniques you can use for culinary experimentation. Seattle foraging teacher Jeremy Puma delves into the world of wild plants and edible weeds, going beyond the basics of salads and stews. Packed with useful theories and delicious recipes, “The Creative Forager” will be a welcome addition to the kitchen bookshelf of anyone interested in eating wild.

Paperback: 154 pages
Publisher: Strange Animal Publications (March 28, 2018)
Language: English
ISBN-10: 0692095446
ISBN-13: 978–0692095447
Product Dimensions: 6 x 0.4 x 9 inches

Purchase the paperback on Amazon.com

Purchase the Amazon Kindle Edition

WHAT THEY’RE SAYING:

“The Creative Forager is a compelling, thoughtful, and philosophical approach to using wild plants. I give it two ‘leaves’ up.” — Dan D’Lyon, Plant Expert
“This curious little tome doesn’t quite know what it wants to be. A manifesto? A cookbook? The ramblings of a delusional pseudo-naturalist? I’m not sure I can recommend this to any but the most ardent devotees of the so-called ‘participatory ecology’ movement.” — Carmen Hersoota, Author of ‘The Fanciest Table in Connecticut’
“BAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!” — Some Goat
“This book should be a part of everyone’s ‘Climate Change Survival Guide.’ Post-apocalyptic dining doesn’t have to be boring!” — Gale T. Shallon, Former Futurist
“_________________________________________________” — The Invisible Man

TABLE OF CONTENTS*:

Part One: Foundations

1 INTRODUCTION
2 VOLUNTEERING AT THE SOIL SEED BANK
3 WHAT IS A “FORAGER,” ANYHOW?
4 MANIFESTO FOR A PARTICIPATORY ECOLOGY
5 ETHICAL FORAGING
6 WILD FLAVOR: A MATTER OF “TASTE”
7 WILD GREENS IN THE KITCHEN
8 WILD EDIBLES: CULINARY KEYS
9 WILD FLAVOR BY FAMILY: DANDELION CROQUETTES
10 PUTTING POTHERBS IN THEIR PLACE
11 “DECODING” WILD INGREDIENTS
12 WILD SEASONING
13 WILD OILS AND VINEGARS
14 GET WEIRD WITH VEGAN “GRASSHOPPERS”

Part Two: A Parade of Plant Profiles

15 DANDELION
16 NIPPLEWORT
17 CHICKWEED
18 PLANTAIN
19 LAMBSQUARTERS
20 BITTERCRESS
21 BROAD-LEAVED AND CURLY DOCK
22 FIREWEED
23 STINGING NETTLE
24 HEDGE MUSTARD
25 OX EYE DAISY
26 CONCLUSION

*Some of this content was previously published on Invironment and in “Wild Flavor.”

OKAY! What are you waiting for, the “zombie apocalypse”? Get your copy, and cook some wild foods today!

THE CREATIVE FORAGER was originally published in Invironment on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Eight Reasons You Shouldn’t Grow Your Own Food
entries.summary:
Contrary to “popular opinion,” gardening is NOT for everyone

So you’re thinking of growing your own food? AWESOME! That is an EXCELLENT idea. Growing your own food is one of the best ways to participate in your local meta-entity. It’s a great way to supplement your family’s diet with nutrient-dense and delicious fruits and vegetables, and to save money and reduce your “carbon footprint” by making less trips to the grocery store. CONGRATULATIONS!

HOWEVER!

Here is a thing:

Growing your own food might not be a good decision for you.

This story is currently available to Medium Members at the following link:

Eight Reasons You Shouldn’t Grow Your Own Food

The story will be unlocked and available to all of our readers after 30 days.

Eight Reasons You Shouldn’t Grow Your Own Food was originally published in Invironment on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
